Amberjack Greater.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State/Federal) - 1 per person/daily
-------
Gulf (State/Federal) - 1 per person/daily
Amberjack Greater.Seasons:
Atlantic (State/Federal) - (CLOSED - April 1, 2026 To April 30, 2026)
-------
Gulf (State/Federal) - (CLOSED - Sept. 27, 2025 To Aug.31, 2026)
Amberjack Greater.Conditions:
Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park.
---
Reef fish gear requirements apply
Amberjack Greater.Gear: Legal - Spears, gigs, hook and line, seine, cast net
Amberjack Greater.Description: Found around wrecks, reefs, and rocky outcrops, typically in 60 to 300 feet of water, though juveniles may be found near the surface. Opportunistic feeders eating squid, crustaceans, and fish.

Jack Yellow.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State) - 100 pounds per person or 2 fish (whichever is greater)
---
Atlantic (Federal) - Regulations no longer in effect
-------
Gulf (State/Federal) - 100 pounds per person or 2 fish (whichever is greater)
Jack Yellow.Conditions:
Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks are required when using natural bait.
---
Reef fish gear requirements apply
Jack Yellow.Gear:
Legal - Hook and line, spear, gig, haul seines, and cast nets
-----
Ilegal - Explosives, chemicals, bang sticks, and fish traps
Jack Yellow.Description: Found in the Gulf of Mexico, the Caribbean, and along the Florida Atlantic coast. They inhabit deep wrecks in summer and shallow reefs/flats in winter. Eats live shrimp on a yellow jig head is the top choice.

Hogfish.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State/Federal) - 1 per person/daily
-------
Gulf (State/Federal) - 5 per person/daily
Hogfish.Seasons:
Atlantic (State/Federal) - (OPEN - Open May 1 To Oct. 31)
-------
Gulf (State/Federal) - (OPEN - Year-Round)
Hogfish.Conditions:
Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park.
---
In the Atlantic reef fish fishery, gear rules require dehooking tools, and as of Jan. 1, 2021, non-stainless steel hooks in all state waters, and non-offset circle hooks N. of 28 ° N. latitude.
-----
NOTICE: Gulf federal waters start North of Cape Sable - 25° 09 North Latitude
Hogfish.Gear: Legal - Spears, gigs, hook and line, seine, cast net
Hogfish.Description: hey inhabit offshore reefs, hard-bottom areas, and rocky ledges, typically in 10-100 feet of water, feeding on mollusks and crustaceans. They use their snouts to dig in the sand for crabs, sea urchins, and mollusks. They are often found in small groups or harems, with one male protecting multiple females.

Ballyhoo.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Ballyhoo.Gear: Legal - Cast net (14 feet or less stretched length), hook and line, landing or dip nets.
Ballyhoo.Description: Young are found in open waters. Adults found in bays and nearshore waters close to reefs.

Bonito.BagLimit: (Atlantic/Gulf) 2 fish or 100 pounds per person/day, whichever is greater.
Bonito.Gear: Legal - Hook and line, spears, gigs, haul seines, and cast nets.

Ladyfish.BagLimit: (Atlantic/Gulf) 2 fish or 100 pounds per person/day, whichever is greater.
Ladyfish.Gear: Legal - Hook and line, spears, gigs, haul seines, and cast nets.
Ladyfish.Description: Lives in tropical and subtropical coastal waters, including the Atlantic seaboard and Gulf of Mexico. Usually found inshore, brackish waters, bays, estuaries, mangrove areas, and even completely fresh water. Feeds from small fish and crustaceans (especially shrimp).

Barracuda Great.BagLimit:
region: Collier thru Martin counties
 limit: 2 per person/day
 limit: 6 per vessel/day
 limit: Over 36 inches 1 per person/vessel.

 region: Rest of State
 limit: 2 fish or 100 pounds
Barracuda Great.MinSize:
region: Collier thru Martin counties
 min: 15 Inches

 region: Rest of state
 min: No limit
Barracuda Great.Conditions: Regional regulations includes all waters off Collier, Monroe, Miami-Dade, Broward, Palm Beach, and Martin counties. Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park.
Barracuda Great.Description: Range inshore to offshore. Young found inshore in seagrass beds. Top predator in reef areas, consuming fishes, squid and shrimp. Consuming larger barracuda may cause ciguatera poisoning.

Pinfish.BagLimit: (Atlantic/Gulf) 2 fish or 100 pounds per person/day, whichever is greater.
Pinfish.Gear: Legal - Hook and line, spears, gigs, haul seines, and cast nets.
Pinfish.Description: Found in the Western Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico, on seagrass beds, coral reefs, rocky bottoms, and estuaries; juveniles prefer shallow water. Daytime feeder omnivorous species, eating algae, seagrass, plankton, small crabs, shrimp, and mollusks. Considered an excellent, underrated panfish, similar to other porgies or snapper.

Pinfish Spottail.BagLimit: (Atlantic/Gulf) 2 fish or 100 pounds per person/day, whichever is greater.
Pinfish Spottail.Gear: Legal - Hook and line, spears, gigs, haul seines, and cast nets.
Pinfish Spottail.Description: Found in the Western Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico, on seagrass beds, coral reefs, rocky bottoms, and estuaries; juveniles prefer shallow water. Daytime feeder omnivorous species, eating algae, seagrass, plankton, small crabs, shrimp, and mollusks. Considered an excellent, underrated panfish, similar to other porgies or snapper.

Bermuda Chub.BagLimit: 2 fish or 100 pounds per person, per day, whichever is greater.
Bermuda Chub.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Bermuda Chub.Gear: Legal - Hook and line, spears, gigs, haul seines, and cast nets.
Bermuda Chub.Description: They are found in the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Oceans, inhabiting shallow coastal areas, rocky bottoms, and coral reefs. Young chubs are often found among floating sargassum seaweed.

Blue Fish.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State) - 3 per person/daily - Nassau thru Miami counties.
Atlantic (Federal) - 3 per person for anglers fishing from private recreational vessels and 5 per person on for-hire vessels.
Gulf (State/Federal) - 10 per person/daily - includes Monroe County
Blue Fish.MinSize:
Atlantic (State) - 12 inches
Atlantic (Federal) - None
Gulf (State/Federal) - 12 inches
Blue Fish.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters)
Blue Fish.Conditions: Keep-Whole - (Must remain in whole condition until landed ashore - head and tail must be intact.)
Blue Fish.Gear: Legal - Hook and line, spears, gigs, seine, cast net
Blue Fish.Description: (May contain elevated mercury levels) - Opportunistic predators that feed on a wide range of prey, including squid, menhaden, and smaller fish. Found in temperate to warm waters in the western Atlantic and other oceans. They are pelagic (open ocean) schooling fish that migrate seasonally, moving north in the spring and south in the fall.

Jack Blue Runner.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Jack Blue Runner.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Jack Blue Runner.Description: Adults feed on fish, shrimp and squid. Juveniles found offshore. Adults found inshore and nearshore.

Bone Fish.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Bone Fish.Conditions: Use of Multiple Hooks is prohibited.
Bone Fish.Description: They feed on bottom-dwelling invertebrates such as clams, snails, crabs, and shrimp, using their specialized mouth to forage in sand and mud. Lives in shallow coastal waters, intertidal flats, mangrove areas, and river mouths. They are found in tropical and subtropical waters worldwide, including the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Oceans.

Butterfly Fish Banded.Description: Omnivorous foragers that eat reef-dwelling invertebrates such as polychaete worms, coral polyps, and anemones. Found in shallow-water coral reefs and rocky areas, primarily the tropical western Atlantic Ocean, including the Caribbean Sea, Gulf of Mexico, and the coasts of Florida, Bermuda, and New England.

Butterfly Fish Foureye.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Butterfly Fish Foureye.Conditions: Organisms must be landed and kept alive, requiring a continuously circulating live well or an adequate aeration/oxygenation system. The sale of recreationally caught marine life organisms is prohibited. Harvesting is prohibited in certain areas, such as the John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park, notes the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission.
Butterfly Fish Foureye.Gear: specific gear, including hand-held nets, drop nets, rod and reel, barrier nets, and slurp guns. The use of quinaldine (a chemical anesthetic) is prohibited.
Butterfly Fish Foureye.Description: They are carnivores that use their pointed mouths to feed on small invertebrates, such as worms, coral polyps, and gorgonians. Usually found in shallow coral reefs, rocky reefs, and seagrass beds at depths of 6–65 feet (2–20 m) in Western Atlantic Ocean, from Massachusetts to Brazil, including the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean.

Butterfly Fish Reef.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Butterfly Fish Reef.Conditions: Harvesting is prohibited in certain areas, such as the John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park, notes the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission.
Butterfly Fish Reef.Gear: Anglers using special gear must comply with specific regulations.
Butterfly Fish Reef.Description: They are carnivorous or omnivorous, primarily eating invertebrates like coral polyps, anemones, worms, and crustaceans. Some species also consume algae. Lives in shallow coral reefs, with some species also found in seagrass beds or near brackish water bays.

Cobia.BagLimit: Gulf and Atlantic (State/Federal) - 1 per person or 2 per vessel, whichever is less.
Cobia.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Cobia.Conditions: Keep-Whole - (Must remain in whole condition until landed ashore - head and tail must be intact.)
Cobia.Gear: Legal - Spears, gigs, hook and line, seine, cast net
Cobia.Description: Found in both inshore and nearshore waters, often near natural and manmade structures like reefs, wrecks, buoys, and pilings.

Croaker Atlantic.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State) - 50 per person/per species.
Gulf (State) - 100 pounds per person
Croaker Atlantic.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Croaker Atlantic.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Croaker Atlantic.Description: Opportunistic bottom feeders, they eat worms, crustaceans (like shrimp and crabs), and small fish. Found over sandy or muddy bottoms in coastal waters, estuaries, and bays. Young fish are typically in estuaries, while older fish move to deeper offshore waters in the winter.

Bass Black Sea.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State) - 7 per person/daily.
Atlantic (Federal) - 7 fish per person
Gulf - 100 pounds per person/daily
Bass Black Sea.MinSize:
Atlantic (State) - 13 inches
Atlantic (Federal) - 13 inches
Gulf - 10 inches
Bass Black Sea.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Bass Black Sea.Conditions: Keep-Whole - (Must remain in whole condition until landed ashore - head and tail must be intact.)
Bass Black Sea.Gear:
Legal - Hook andd Line, Spears
Atlantic - dehooking device and as of Jan. 1, 2021, non-stainless steel hooks in all state waters, and non-offset circle hooks N. of 28 ° N. latitude.
Gulf - non-stainless-steel, non-offset circle hooks; dehooking device.
Bass Black Sea.Description: They are found in the coastal waters near structure and rocky bottoms. Smaller specimens are often found inshore in finger channels. Up to 24 inches (8 pounds), common to 12 inches (1.5 pounds)

Drum Black.BagLimit: 5 per harvester per day (can include one (1) over 24 inches)
Drum Black.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Drum Black.Conditions: Keep-Whole - Must remain in whole condition until landed ashore. Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park
Drum Black.Gear:
Legal - Hook and line, cast net, seine, spear or gig
Ilegal - Cannot harvest using any multiple hook in conjunction with live or dead natural bait, snatching prohibited
Drum Black.Description: Bottom-feeders that use their chin barbels to find and their strong throat teeth to crush prey like clams, oysters, crabs, worms, and other shellfish. Coastal bays, sounds, inlets, and river mouths, and can be found around oyster beds, docks, and bridge pilings.

Drum Red.BagLimit:
Panhandle - 1 per person/daily or 4 per vessel/daily.
Big Bend - 1 per person/daily or 4 per vessel/daily.
Tampa Bay - 1 per person/daily or 2 per vessel/daily.
Sarasota Bay - 1 per person/daily or 2 per vessel/daily
Charlotte Harbor - 1 per person/daily or 2 per vessel/daily
Southwest - 1 per person/daily or 2 per vessel/daily
Southeast - 1 per person/daily or 2 per vessel/daily
Indian River Lagoon - CATCH-AND-RELEASE
Northeast - 1 per person/daily or 4 per vessel/daily
Drum Red.MinSize:
Not less than 18 inches in the following regions.
Panhandle
Big Bed
Tampa Bay
Sarasota Bay
Charlotte Harbor
Southwest
Southeast
Northeast
Drum Red.MaxSize:
No more than 27 inches in the following regions.
Panhandle
Big Bed
Tampa Bay
Sarasota Bay
Charlotte Harbor
Southwest
Southeast
Northeast
Drum Red.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Drum Red.Conditions:
Keep-Whole - Must remain in whole condition until landed ashore - head and tail must be intact.
 Other Regulations - Bag limits apply in areas adjacent to fishing sites such as docks and parking lots. 4 fish per person transport limit applies when traveling in a vehicle on land away from a fishing site. Captain and Crew bag limit prohibited while on a for-hire trip. Commercial harvest prohibited

 *ALWAYS CHECK THE REGIONS FIRST*
Drum Red.Gear:
Legal - Hook and line, cast nets
Ilegal - Spearing (includes spearfishing, gigging and bowfishing, and snatch hooking) and/or use of multiple hooks in conjunction with live or dead natural bait is prohibited
Drum Red.Description: Bottom feeders that prey on crabs, shrimp, and small fish. Found in coastal and estuarine waters from Massachusetts to Key West, Florida, and along the entire Gulf coast to northern Mexico.

Drum Spotted.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Drum Spotted.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Drum Spotted.Description: Also known as the (Spotted Ribbonfish) is a Nocturnal feeder. At night, it leaves its shelter to feed on small crustaceans (like shrimp and crabs) and polychaete worms found in the substrate. It primarily inhabits coral reefs, in shallow lagoons, reef faces, and near pier pilings. Found in the warmer, tropical waters of the Western Atlantic Ocean, from South Florida to Brazil, including the Bahamas, the Gulf of Mexico, and the Caribbean Sea.

Flounder Gulf.Conditions: Regulations apply to Gulf flounder, Southern flounder, summer flounder and fringed flounder. Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park.
Flounder Gulf.Gear:
Legal - Spears, gigs, hook and line, seine, cast net.
Ilegal - Harvest of this species by snagging (snatch hooking) or with the use of any multiple hooks in conjunction with live or dead natural bait is prohibited.
Flounder Gulf.Description: Caught with various methods, including hook and line, jigs, and gigging, especially at night in shallow waters. Inhabits sandy or muddy bottoms in coastal waters, bays, and tidal creeks. Juveniles are often found in higher salinity seagrass beds.

Flounder Peacock Atlantic.Gear:
Legal - Spears, gigs, hook and line, seine, cast net.
Ilegal - Harvest of this species by snagging (snatch hooking) or with the use of any multiple hooks in conjunction with live or dead natural bait is prohibited.
Flounder Peacock Atlantic.Description: Caught with various methods, including hook and line, jigs, and gigging, especially at night in shallow waters. Inhabits sandy or muddy bottoms in coastal waters, bays, and tidal creeks. Juveniles are often found in higher salinity seagrass beds.

Goatfish Spotted.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Goatfish Spotted.Conditions: Sale is prohibited for recreationally caught marine life organisms. Collection is prohibited in certain areas, such as the Blue Heron Bridge dive site and John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park.
Goatfish Spotted.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Goatfish Spotted.Description: Primarily feeds on bottom-dwelling invertebrates such as crabs, shrimp, worms, and mollusks. Found in shallow waters near reefs, over sand or rocky bottoms, and juveniles can be found in seagrass beds.

GoatFish Yellow Saddle.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
GoatFish Yellow Saddle.Conditions: All harvested organisms must be kept alive and in a continuously circulating live well or aeration system.
GoatFish Yellow Saddle.Gear: Hook and line, hand-held net, drop net, barrier net, or slurp gun.(Use of quinaldine is prohibited)
GoatFish Yellow Saddle.Description: As carnivores, they eat meaty foods such as shrimp, crustaceans, worms, and other small invertebrates. They spend a significant amount of time sifting through the sand to find small prey like invertebrates and worms. Found in the Indo-Pacific, on coral reefs, rubble areas, and lagoons.

GoatFish Yellowstripe.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
GoatFish Yellowstripe.Conditions: All harvested organisms must be kept alive and in a continuously circulating live well or aeration system.
GoatFish Yellowstripe.Gear: Hook and line, hand-held net, drop net, barrier net, or slurp gun.(Use of quinaldine is prohibited)
GoatFish Yellowstripe.Description: Eats worms, crustaceans, mollusks, and small invertebrates. Found in sandy areas of lagoons and seaward reefs, often schooling in the water column over reefs between 1 and 76 meters (3 to 250 feet) deep.

Grouper Black.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State/Federal)
1 gag or black within the 3 grouper aggregate

Vessel limit 2 black per vessel per day, not to exceed the daily bag limit, whichever is more restrictive
For-hire captain and crew retention prohibited

Gulf (State)
4 per person within 4 grouper aggregate
0 for Charter Captain and Crew

Gulf (Federal)
4 per person within 4 grouper aggregate
Grouper Black.Seasons:
Atlantic (State/Federal)
CLOSED - January 01, 2026 To Apr 30, 2026
*Season re-opens May 1, 2026

Gulf (State)
Open year-round

Gulf (Federal)
Closed February 1, 2026 to March 31, 2026 seaward of 20 fathoms
'The Edges' CLOSED January 1, 2026 to April 30, 2026
Grouper Black.Conditions:
Keep-Whole - Must remain in whole condition until landed ashore - head and tail must be intact.

Aggregate Limits
Atlantic 3
Gulf 4

Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park.

Atlantic Regulations for state and federal waters unless specified, excluding all state waters of Monroe County, Atlantic state waters are from shore to 3 miles

Gulf of America Regulations for state and federal waters unless specified, excluding all state waters of Monroe County, Gulf state waters are from shore to 9 miles
Grouper Black.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending device or venting tool rigged and ready is required when fishing for reef fish. Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks when fishing with natural bait.
Grouper Black.Description: Primarily eats fish, squid and crustaceans. Adults prefer rocky bottoms, reefs, and drop-off walls, while juveniles can be found in seagrass beds and oyster rubble. Usually found in the Western Atlantic, from Massachusetts to Brazil, including the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean.

Grouper Coney.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State/Federal)
Up to 3 per person within 3 grouper aggregate

Gulf (State/Federal)
Up to 4 per person within the 4 grouper aggregate

Gulf of America Regulations for state and federal waters unless specified, excluding all state waters of Monroe County, Gulf state waters are from shore to 9 miles
Grouper Coney.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending device or venting tool rigged and ready is required when fishing for reef fish. Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks when fishing with natural bait.
Grouper Coney.Description: Primarily eats small reef fish, crustaceans, crabs, and shrimp. Found in reef areas, seagrass beds, and around caves and crevices.

Grouper Gag.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State/Federal)
1 Gag or Black within the 3 grouper aggregate
Vessel limit 2 gag per vessel per day, not to exceed the daily bag limit, whichever is more restrictive
For-hire captain and crew retention prohibited

Gulf (State/Federal)
2 per person/daily within 4 grouper aggregate
0 for Charter Captain and Crew

CLOSED - From June 26, 2025 to May 1, 2026)

Atlantic Regulations for state and federal waters unless specified, excluding all state waters of Monroe County, Atlantic state waters are from shore to 3 miles

Gulf of America Regulations for state and federal waters unless specified, excluding all state waters of Monroe County, Gulf state waters are from shore to 9 miles
Grouper Gag.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending device or venting tool rigged and ready is required when fishing for reef fish. Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks when fishing with natural bait.
Grouper Gag.Description: Adults primarily eat a variety of fish, crabs, shrimp, and squid. Juvenile gag groupers, less than 8 inches, feed on crustaceans in shallow seagrass beds.  Adults are typically found on rocky reefs and other hard-bottom habitats from coastal waters down to 500 feet. They can be found from North Carolina to Brazil.

Grouper Goliath.Seasons:
CLOSED 

OPEN -(March 1,2026 to March 31,2026 ONLY for permit/tag holders
Grouper Goliath.Conditions: Harvest Prohibited without Permit. Permits in Florida allow for a highly regulated, limited harvest in state waters via a random lottery system (200 permits) and (registration opens October 1st - 15th), costing residents $150 and non-residents $500, plus a $10 application fee. Winners get one tag for the March 1 - May 31 season, catching only hook-and-line caught fish within a 24-36 inch slot, with specific closed areas (like Keys and Martin Co Atlantic) and mandatory reporting, tagging after harvest.
Grouper Goliath.Description: Found in coastal and nearshore waters, often near natural and man-made structures like bridges, docks, and artificial reefs. They also inhabit estuaries, especially around mangroves.

Grouper Graysby.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State/Federal)
Up to 3 per person within 3 grouper aggregate

Gulf (State/Federal)
Up to 4 per person within the 4 grouper aggregate
Grouper Graysby.Seasons:
Atlantic (State/Federal)
CLOSED - (January 01, 2026 To Apr 30, 2026)
*Season re-opens May 1, 2026

Gulf (State/Federal)

Atlantic Regulations for state and federal waters unless specified, excluding all state waters of Monroe County, Atlantic state waters are from shore to 3 miles

Gulf of America Regulations for state and federal waters unless specified, excluding all state waters of Monroe County, Gulf state waters are from shore to 9 miles
Grouper Graysby.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending device or venting tool rigged and ready is required when fishing for reef fish. Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks when fishing with natural bait.
Grouper Graysby.Description: Primarily eats small reef fish, crustaceans, crabs, and shrimp. Found in reef areas, seagrass beds, and around caves and crevices.

Grouper Nassau.Description: (If you accidentally catch one, you must release it immediately and handle it with care.) They eat crustaceans and smaller fish. Juveniles eat crustaceans and bivalves, while larger adults feed on fish, lobsters, and gastropods.  Their range is limited to south Florida and the Florida Keys, with their presence on the Gulf side being rare. Adults are found on coral reefs and rocky bottoms, while juveniles are found in seagrass beds closer to shore.

Grouper Tiger.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending device or venting tool rigged and ready is required when fishing for reef fish. Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks when fishing with natural bait.
Grouper Tiger.Description: Carnivorous, eating smaller fish, crabs, shrimp, and octopus. Solitary ambush predator, using camouflage to surprise prey like fish, crabs, and squid. Found in warm, clear waters of Western Atlantic reefs, from Florida to Brazil; adults prefer deeper reefs, juveniles use seagrass beds.

Grouper Yellowfin.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.) - Federal Waters: Closed - Feb 1 - March 31 seaward of 20 fathoms, (The Edges) Jan 1 - Apr 30.
Grouper Yellowfin.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending device or venting tool rigged and ready is required when fishing for reef fish. Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks when fishing with natural bait.
Grouper Yellowfin.Description: Adults prefer rocky/coral reefs and ledges; juveniles live in seagrass beds and mangroves. Carnivorous, eating smaller fish and cephalopods. Known to carry ciguatera toxin, so caution is needed when eating.

Grunt Porkfish.BagLimit: 0 (When fishing for dinner), 10 (For live capture - Aquarium Display)
Grunt Porkfish.Conditions: (Aquarium Species) You may only collect them if you intend on displaying them in a saltwater aquarium. If you harvest any aquarium species, they must be kept alive and landed alive. They must be maintained in a continuously circulating live well, aeration or oxygenation system of adequate size to maintain these organisms in a healthy condition is required. Regulations apply in both state and federal waters.
Grunt Porkfish.Gear: Hand-held nets, drop nets, barrier nets, and slurp guns.
Grunt Porkfish.Description: Primarily nocturnal predators of invertebrates, such as mollusks, crustaceans, and worms.  Found in shallow waters, from 6 to 65 feet deep, over reefs and rocky bottoms. Juveniles are often found in seagrass beds.

Jack Crevalle.BagLimit: 2 or 100 pounds per person, whichever is greater
Jack Crevalle.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Jack Crevalle.Gear: Standard recreational gear such as hook and line, spears, and cast nets.
Jack Crevalle.Description: Feeds on smaller fish, shrimp, and invertebrates and is known for being a powerful fighter. Found in a variety of environments, including offshore waters, reefs, seagrass beds, and estuaries. They can also move into brackish and even freshwater tributaries. Widespread in the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico, from the shoreline to open water.

Needle Fish.BagLimit: 2 or 100 pounds per person, whichever is greater
Needle Fish.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Needle Fish.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Needle Fish.Description: Primarily eats small fish. Younger fish that have not yet developed a full (beak) eat plankton. Primarily found in shallow, coastal marine waters, bays, and estuaries, but some species can also be found in freshwater rivers and canals.

Pompano Florida.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Pompano Florida.Conditions: Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park.
Pompano Florida.Gear: Hook and line, cast net and beach or haul seine only. Multiple hooks or snatching prohibited.
Pompano Florida.Description: Eats small clams, sand fleas, and other small invertebrates. Prefers sandy surf flats and nearshore areas. Found along the Atlantic coast from Massachusetts to Brazil, with high concentrations near Florida.

Pompano African.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Pompano African.Conditions: Keep-Whole. Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park.
Pompano African.Gear: Hook and line only. Multiple hooks or snatching prohibited.
Pompano African.Description: Found in tropical and subtropical seas worldwide, including the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific Oceans. Prefers coastal waters, reefs, and wrecks, often in depths from near the surface to deeper waters. Feeds on crabs, shrimp, and small fish; they are known to prefer live food. Use live shrimp, pilchards, squid, sand fleas. Combine slow pitch jigging, using jigs that mimic injured baitfish; can also be caught on lures, with fly fishing, or drifting live bait.

Shark Bull.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Shark Bull.Conditions: Multiple hooks or snatching prohibited. Sharks must be landed whole. Head, tail, and fins must remain attached until processed after landing. This does not prohibit gutting or slicing the base of the caudal fin to bleed the shark.
Shark Bull.Gear: Only hook and line gear is permitted. You must use non-offset, non-stainless-steel circle hooks when fishing with live or dead natural bait. You must be able to quickly cut the leader or hook to release prohibited species without delay. Flatten or file down hook barbs.
Shark Bull.Description: Bull sharks are opportunistic feeders with a wide diet that includes fish, seals, birds, dolphins, sea turtles, and other sharks. Found in warm, coastal waters worldwide, they are one of the few sharks that can tolerate freshwater and are often found in rivers and estuaries. (Shore-based anglers: You must take and pass the Shore-Based Shark Fishing Course online and carry the free permit with you at all times. Charter boat anglers: The captain typically holds the license, but you are still responsible for following all regulations.)

Grunt White.BagLimit: No established bag limit. General limit of 100 pounds applies.
Grunt White.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Grunt White.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Grunt White.Description: Nocturnal carnivore, eating shrimp, crabs, mollusks, small fish, and worms. Found in coastal to offshore, favoring reefs, seagrass, sand flats, and hard bottoms from Virginia to Brazil, Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean Sea

Wahoo.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Wahoo.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Wahoo.Description: Aggressive predators that feed on other fish, including mackerel, butterfish, and porcupine fish. Pelagic, meaning they live in open water, often near the surface, but can also be found deeper near drop-offs and shipwrecks, they are often drawn to floating objects.  Found in tropical and subtropical waters worldwide in the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific oceans.

Dolphinfish.BagLimit: Person: 5, Vessel 30. Bag and possession limit for captains and crew on for-hire vessels is zero.
Dolphinfish.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Dolphinfish.Conditions: Keep-Whole - Must remain in whole condition until landed ashore - head and tail must be intact.
Dolphinfish.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Dolphinfish.Description: Hunts small fish (like flying fish), crabs, and other small marine life. Lives near the surface in warm, tropical/subtropical waters worldwide, often schooling as juveniles and alone as adults.

Snapper Yellowtail.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Snapper Yellowtail.Conditions: Keep-Whole - Must remain in whole condition until landed ashore - head and tail must be intact. Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending Device/Venting Tool
Snapper Yellowtail.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Snapper Yellowtail.Description: Invertebrates (shrimp, crabs, worms) and small fish, also plankton. Forms large schools, especially juveniles in seagrass; adults near reefs, often above the bottom. Coastal reefs in the Western Atlantic, from Massachusetts to Brazil, especially abundant in the Caribbean and Florida Keys.

Snapper Cubera.BagLimit: 10 (Aggregate Limit: 10). Only 2 over 30 Inches per person/vessel daily, which ever is less.
Snapper Cubera.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Snapper Cubera.Conditions: Keep-Whole - Must remain in whole condition until landed ashore - head and tail must be intact (Removal of gills and guts allowed).
Snapper Cubera.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending Device/Venting Tool.
Snapper Cubera.Description: Powerful predators of fish and large crustaceans, using their strong jaws. Adults prefer offshore rocky ledges, wrecks, and reefs; juveniles live inshore in seagrass beds and mangroves. Can exceed 120 pounds and reach over 5 feet long, though commonly around 40 pounds. Dark brown or gray, sometimes with a reddish tinge; large canine teeth, with one prominent pair visible when the mouth is closed; bluish tinge on fins in some Persons.

Snapper Mutton.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Snapper Mutton.Conditions: Keep Whole - Removal of gills and guts allowed.
Snapper Mutton.Gear: Circle hooks, non-stainless steel hooks, dehooking device use required as needed, descending device/venting tool.
Snapper Mutton.Description: Opportunistic predators eating crustaceans (shrimp, crabs), mollusks, small fish, and squid. Active day and night, picking prey from surfaces, and adopting darker, barred patterns when feeding near the bottom. Found in the Western Atlantic, from Massachusetts to Brazil, common in Florida, the Caribbean, and Gulf of Mexico. Lives in shallow, clear waters near reefs, seagrass beds, and mangroves as juveniles, moving to deeper offshore reefs as adults.

Snapper Red.BagLimit:
Atlantic: (State) - 2 per person
 Atlantic (Federal) - 1 per person

Gulf (State/Federal): 2 per person
(included in the 10 per harvester per day state snapper aggregate bag limit).
Charter captain and crew: 0
Snapper Red.Seasons:
Atlantic (State) - OPENN
Atlantic (Federal) - CLOSED

Gulf (State/Federal) - 2026 Season is closed Jan. 1 until season is announced.
Snapper Red.Conditions: Keep Whole - Removal of gills and guts allowed.
Snapper Red.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending device or venting tool rigged and ready is required when fishing for reef fish. Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks when fishing with natural bait.
Snapper Red.Description: Found in the Gulf of Mexico and along the Atlantic coast, preferring offshore structures like reefs, wrecks, and oil rigs. Carnivores, eating fish, shrimp, crabs, squid, and worms.

Snapper Vermilion.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State/Federal): 5 per person (not included in the 10 snapper aggregate bag limit).

Gulf (State) - 10 per person (not included in the 10 snapper aggregate bag limit)
Gulf (Federal) -  10/person (Within 20 reef fish aggregate).
Snapper Vermilion.Conditions: Keep Whole - Removal of gills and guts allowed.
Snapper Vermilion.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending device or venting tool rigged and ready is required when fishing for reef fish. Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks when fishing with natural bait.
Snapper Vermilion.Description: Found in waters 60-400 feet deep, often over reefs, rocks, and sand. Offshore, from North Carolina to Brazil, in the Gulf of Mexico. Adults form large schools near structures. Eats fish, shrimp, crabs, squid, worms, and plankton

Snapper Lane.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State/Federal): 10 per person (Within the 10 snapper aggregate bag limit).

Gulf (State) - Bag limit of 100 pounds .
Gulf (Federal) - 20 under their 20-reef fish aggregate
Snapper Lane.Conditions: Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park.
Snapper Lane.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending device or venting tool rigged and ready is required when fishing for reef fish. Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks when fishing with natural bait.
Snapper Lane.Description: Found in inshore over seagrass beds as juveniles, moving to deeper coral reefs and structures as adults. Usually under 14 inches, but can grow larger. Feeds from shrimp, squid, cut bait, and minnows work well.

Snapper Gray Mangrove.BagLimit:
---
Atlantic Gulf (State): 5 per person (Within the 10 snapper aggregate bag limit).
---
Atlantic (Federal) - 10 per person within the 10 snapper aggregate bag limit.
-------
Gulf (State) - 5 per person within the 10 snapper aggregate bag limit.
---
Gulf (Federal) - 10 per person within the 10 snapper aggregate bag limit.
Snapper Gray Mangrove.MinSize:
Atlantic (State): 10 Inches
---
Atlantic (Federal): 12 Inches
-------
Gulf (State): 10 Inches
---
Gulf (Federal): 12 Inches
Snapper Gray Mangrove.Conditions: Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park.
Snapper Gray Mangrove.Gear: Dehooking device use required as needed. Descending device or venting tool rigged and ready is required when fishing for reef fish. Non-stainless steel, non-offset circle hooks when fishing with natural bait.
Snapper Gray Mangrove.Description: Found in the Indian and Western Pacific Oceans. Juveniles often live in mangrove-lined estuaries, moving to deep, offshore reefs and wrecks as they mature. They are opportunistic carnivores that feed on small fish, crustaceans (shrimp, crabs), and cephalopods, particularly at night. They are notorious for being cautious, (bait-stealing) fish, requiring light tackle and fluorocarbon leaders. Yes, they will bite, so keep fingers away from their mouths.

Sheepshead.BagLimit:
Atlantic/Gulf (State/Federal) - 8 per Person
Atlantic/Gulf (State/Federal) - 50 per vessel, per trip during March and April
Sheepshead.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Sheepshead.Conditions: State regulations extend into federal waterse
Sheepshead.Gear:
Legal - Hook and line, cast net, seine, spear or gig.
Ilegal - Harvest prohibited by or with the use of any multiple hook in conjunction with live or dead natural bait, Snatching prohibited
Sheepshead.Description: Found near piers, pilings, jetties, reefs, and oyster beds in coastal waters. Carnivores eating crustaceans, mollusks (crabs, oysters, clams) using powerful jaws. Use light tackle and be quick to set the hook; chumming with crushed shells helps. Fiddler crabs, live shrimp, barnacles, and clams work best.

Mackerel Cero.BagLimit: 2 fish or 100 lbs person/day which ever is more (Unregulated Species)
Mackerel Cero.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Mackerel Cero.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Mackerel Cero.Description: Common in clear, tropical/subtropical waters, especially around coral reefs, wrecks, and structure from New England to Brazil, but most abundant in the Florida Keys and Caribbean. Eats small schooling fish (sardines, herring) and squid.

Mackerel King.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Mackerel King.Conditions: Keep-Whole - Removal of gills and guts allowed. Atlantic state waters (excludes Monroe County)
Mackerel King.Description: Found in coastal or open ocean waters, migrates seasonally with water temperatures. Opportunistic carnivores, eating menhaden, mullet, herring, sardines, squid, and shrimp.

Mackerel Spanish Atlantic.Seasons: OPEN - (Presently, there is no closed season for this species in these waters.)
Mackerel Spanish Atlantic.Conditions: Keep-Whole - Removal of gills and guts allowed
Mackerel Spanish Atlantic.Gear: Any legal gear for saltwater fishing
Mackerel Spanish Atlantic.Description: Migrates along the U.S. Atlantic Coast from Florida (winter) north to New York/New England (summer) and into the Gulf of Mexico. Forms large, fast-moving schools near the surface in coastal waters, barrier islands, and passes. Eats smaller fish (mullet, sardines, anchovies), shrimp, and crustaceans, often driving prey to the surface.

Snook Common.BagLimit:
1 fish per person/day applies per region
------
Panhandle (PH)
Big Bend Region (BB)
Tampa Bay Region (TB)
Sarasota Bay Region (SB)
Charlotte Harbor Region (CH)
Southwest Region (SW)
Southeast Region (SE)
Indian River Lagoon Region (IRL)
Northeast Region
Snook Common.Seasons:
CLOSED - (December 1­­ – end of February, and May 1 – August 31)
---
Panhandle
Big Bend
Tampa Bay
Sarasota Bay

CLOSED - (December 1 – end of February, and May 1 – September 30)
---
Charlotte Harbor
Southwest

CLOSED - (December 15 – January 31, and June 1 – August 31)
---
Southeast
Indian River Lagoon
Northeast
Snook Common.Conditions:
Regulations apply in all inland, state and adjacent federal waters.
---
No commercial harvest or sale of snook is permitted.
---
Must remain in whole condition until landed ashore.
---
When on a for-hire trip, captain and crew may not retain a bag limit.

Snook permit and recreational fishing license required

Prior to purchasing a snook permit, check current regulations in the area you plan to fish. All sales are final. Refunds will not be given even if the species you plan to target is closed to harvest.
Snook Common.Description:
Found in coastal waters, estuaries, mangroves, and sometimes freshwater, particularly in Florida and the Gulf of Mexico. Highly euryhaline, allowing them to thrive in both saltwater and freshwater, often moving between them for spawning. Opportunistic predators that feed on fish, crabs, and shrimp.

Regions:
-----
The western boundary is located at the Florida-Alabama border and the region extends to the eastern coastal boundary at 84°20.800 West Longitude in Franklin County near Alligator Point.
-----
The western coastal boundary is located at 84°20.800 West Longitude in Franklin County near Alligator Point. The region extends east and south to Fred Howard Park, near the border of Pasco and Pinellas counties. Includes all waters of the Ochlockonee, Withlacoochee, and Anclote rivers and their tributaries.
-----
The northern coastal boundary is located at Fred Howard Park, near the border of Pasco and Pinellas counties and the region extends south to State Road 64 in Manatee County. Includes all waters of the Alafia, Braden, Manatee, and Hillsborough rivers and their tributaries. Does not include the waters of Palma Sola Bay and all waters of the Anclote River and its tributaries.
-----
The northern coastal boundary is located at State Road 64 in Manatee County and the region extends south to 27°04.727 North Latitude, near the Venice Municipal Airport. Includes all waters of Palma Sola Bay, Phillippi Creek, Cow Pen Slough Canal and Curry Creek. Does not include the waters of the Braden and Manatee rivers.
-----
The northern coastal boundary is located at 27°04.727 North Latitude, near the Venice Municipal Airport, and the region extends south to 26°15.227 North Latitude, near Vanderbilt Beach Rd in Collier County. Includes all waters of the Caloosahatchee, Myakka, and Peace rivers and their tributaries. Does not include Lake Okeechobee.
-----
The northern boundary is located at 26°15.227 North Latitude, near Vanderbilt Beach Rd in Collier County, and the region extends through the Florida Keys to the Monroe/Miami-Dade county line. Includes all inland waters and all waters of Everglades National Park.
-----
The northern boundary is the Martin-Palm Beach county line and the region extends south to the Miami-Dade/Monroe county line. Includes all waters of Hillsboro Canal, Miami Canal, North New River Canal, and West Palm Beach Canal, and the Loxahatchee River and its tributaries. Does not include Lake Okeechobee and Everglades National Park.
Special regulations apply for this species when fishing in Biscayne National Park.
-----
The northern coastal boundary is located at Lytle Avenue/South Causeway in New Smyrna Beach and the region extends south to the Martin-Palm Beach county line. Includes all inland waters of the area, and all waters of the Kissimmee River, Lake Okeechobee and other lakes identified on the map with blue hatch. Does not include the waters of Loxahatchee and St. Johns rivers and their tributaries.
-----
The northern coastal boundary is located at the Florida-Georgia border and the region extends south to the Lytle Avenue/South Causeway in New Smyrna Beach. Includes all inland waters of the area, and the waters of the St. Johns River and its tributaries. Does not include the waters of the Withlacoochee and Kissimmee rivers, Cypress Lake, and lakes Hatchineha and Kissimmee.

Mullet.BagLimit:
Atlantic/Gulf (State/Federal)
-------
50 per Person
---
50 per Vessel (Sept. 1 - Jan. 31)
---
100 per Vessel (Feb. 1 - Aug. 31)
Mullet.Conditions: More restrictive seasonal bag limits apply to portions of Pinellas County, and seasonal night closures apply in portions of Charlotte County.
Mullet.Gear:
Legal - hook and line, spears, gigs, seine, cast net.
---
Ilegal - spearfishing mullet in fresh water prohibited
Mullet.Description: Found worldwide in tropical and temperate seas, often near shores, estuaries, and even freshwater, swimming in schools. Primarily eat algae, detritus (decaying organic matter), phytoplankton, and zooplankton.

Porgy Red.BagLimit:
Atlantic (State/Federal)
---
1 fish per person
-------
Gulf (State/Federal)
---
2 fish or 100 lbs. per person, whichever is more.
Porgy Red.Seasons:
Atlantic (State/Federal)
---
CLOSED (re-opens May - June)
-------
Gulf (State/Federal) - OPEN
Porgy Red.Gear: Legal - hook and line, spears, gigs
Porgy Red.Description: Found in rocky or sandy bottoms, typically at depths of 90 to 350 feet on the continental shelf. Carnivorous, feeding on crustaceans (crabs, shrimp), mollusks (snails, clams), sea urchins, worms, and small fish.

Permit.BagLimit: Person: 2 (1 over 22 inches), Vessel: 2 over 22 inches (daily). (SPZ) Person: 1, Vessel: 2
Permit.Seasons: OPEN unless fishing on the Special Permit Zone - (Closed April 1-July 31).
Permit.Gear: Hook and line only. Multiple hooks or snatching prohibited.
Permit.Description:
Found in shallow, warm inshore waters like flats, channels, and near reefs in the Western Atlantic, especially abundant in South Florida and the Caribbean. Opportunistic feeders, using their crushing teeth to eat crabs, mollusks, and sea urchins, often digging in the seafloor.

The Special Permit Zone includes state and adjacent federal waters south of a line running due east from Cape Florida in the Atlantic at 25° 40 North Latitude, waters of Biscayne Bay south of Rickenbacker Causeway, and south of a line just south of Cape Sable running due west through federal waters at 25° 09 North Latitude.
